Feminist, intersectional thinking would also be [...]

Read More... from PhD Scholarships at City

The post PhD Scholarships at City appeared first on Alex Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
We’d love to have
applications from prospective students wanting to join the Centre for Human-Computer Interaction Design (HCID).

The deadline is 20th May 2020. For details and application process, see here.

Topically, I’m very open to suggestions. I’d love to see proposals taking critical and perhaps materialist orientations to technoscience. Feminist, intersectional thinking would also be high on my wish list.

Whatever the persuasion, if you have friends, students, colleagues, etc. interested in doing something exciting, please put them in touch.

The post PhD Scholarships at City appeared first on Alex Taylor.

item.title: Bauhaus Futures Book Chapter
item.dc:creator: Alex Taylor
item.description:
This chapter examines the processes of scaling made visible within the words and work of the Weimer Bauhaus and, particularly, Anni Albers’ careful accounts of weaving. We explore whether threading a feminist precarity into her writing helps illuminate new ways of examining tensions between what we scale up and what we scale down. Reading [...]

Read More... from Bauhaus Futures Book Chapter

The post Bauhaus Futures Book Chapter appeared first on Alex Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
This chapter examines the processes of scaling made visible within the words and work of the Weimer Bauhaus and, particularly, Anni Albers’ careful accounts of weaving. We explore whether threading a feminist precarity into her writing helps illuminate new ways of examining tensions between what we scale up and what we scale down.

Reading with Anni Albers:
The weave as a lively involution of scale, affect, and feminist precarity

Moving first over and across, we examine Alber’s discussions of different scales of weaving, from the hand loom to industrial machinery. Traversing then downward and below, we consider Alber’s attention to the body, those fingers and hands interlacing threads along a pliable plane. Shifting around and through, we consider how an affect is present in Alber’s reflections, and especially in how it pulls against the sturdy mechanistic logics visibly organizing her process. Across this writing, we hope to think with Albers, reading her prose somewhat against the grain of conventional Bauhaus accounts by interweaving a feminist positioning.

Matt Ratto, Daniela K Rosner, Yana Boeva, Alex Taylor (2019) Special issue on hybrid pedagogies editorial, Digital Creativity 30(4), p. 13–217, url, doi:10.1080/14626268.2019.1699576

Daniela K Rosner, Alex S Taylor (2019) Reading with Anni Albers: The Weave as a Lively Involution of Scale, Affect, and Feminist Precarity, Bauhaus Futures, Laura Forlano, Molly Wright Steenson, Mike Ananny (ed.), p. 201–212, Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, pdf

The post Bauhaus Futures Book Chapter appeared first on Alex Taylor.

item.title: A changing academic life
item.dc:creator: Alex Taylor
item.description:
[...]

Read More... from A changing academic life

The post A changing academic life appeared first on Alex Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
So grateful to Geraldine Fitzpatrick for spending the time talking to me and giving me the chance to put words to my still ill-formed thoughts on living an academic life. Such a privilege to be part of her podcast series, Changing Academic Life.

In talking to Geraldine, I’ve tried to be honest, finding space between my naivety and the intellectual environment I’d love to help build with the many amazing academics I work with. Find the podcast and abbreviated transcript here (along with some other great interviews: I highly recommend Ali Black’s).

New podcast with @alxndrt on research at the boundaries, moving from industry to academia, the labour of academia & the power of the collective https://t.co/E6ppqPQux6

— ChangingAcademicLife (@ChangeAcadLife) July 24, 2019

The post A changing academic life appeared first on Alex Taylor.

item.title: Are you Research Excellent?
item.dc:creator: Alex Taylor
item.description:
The UK’s national Research Excellence Framework (REF) assessment is looming. The formal deadline is in 2021, but many will be already feeling the pressures in their institutions and departments to be making sense of their work in terms of REF’s metrics and procedures. I’ve found myself entangled in this world of REF recently and wanting [...]

Read More... from Are you Research Excellent?

The post Are you Research Excellent? appeared first on Alex Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
The UK’s national Research Excellence Framework (REF) assessment is looming. The formal deadline is in 2021, but many will be already feeling the pressures in their institutions and departments to be making sense of their work in terms of REF’s metrics and procedures.
I’ve found myself entangled in this world of REF recently and wanting to be able to make comparisons between institutions and their “Units of Assessment” (REFs classification of research disciplines and fields).
Using this publicly available data, I’ve built a little tool to see how an institution’s unit of assessment did in the last assessment (circa 2014) and view this against other UoA results.

For now, I’m just visualising data from two units of assessment, Sociology and Computer Sciences and Informatics.
You can compare your own institution’s Sociology or Computer Science scores against others’ in terms of Outputs, Impact and Environment (the REF assessment profiles).
I post this sensitive to the troubles and complications that come with enacting academic life using these systems of accounting. I’m grateful to Effie Le Moignan for reminding me of the troubles.

The post Are you Research Excellent? appeared first on Alex Taylor.

item.title: From the Picket Line
item.dc:creator: Alex Taylor
item.description:
For those of us in UK academia, it’s been impossible to miss the strikes over the last four weeks, with academics from across the country standing their ground for a fair and equitable pension. There are many incredibly detailing the developments and explaining how this is about for a walk of life that just doesn’t [...]

Read More... from From the Picket Line

The post From the Picket Line appeared first on Alex Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
For those of us in UK academia, it’s been impossible to miss the strikes over the last four weeks, with academics from across the country standing their ground for a fair and equitable pension. There are many incredibly detailing the developments and explaining how this is about for a walk of life that just doesn’t have to be subject to the warped values of the Neo-liberal project.

Personally, what I’ve found inspirational is the coverage from the picket line and the industry of others. Naturally, there have been the marches, the banners, and the teach-ins. But, with such generative care and warmth, what has brought special cheer to me have been the many outstanding examples of creative impulse: of craft (like that recorded by Jacob Phelps below), of design (from Katja May, Kat Jungnickel, etc. at Goldsmiths), and of poetry (no less from the fabulous Michael Rosen).

Given it would be hard to add to all the amazing commentary on the pension strikes, what I want to pay special homage to here is the dance (and a little song) from the picket line. Browsing the not-so-distant twitter archive, I’ve tried to dig out a few out the highlights from the last few weeks that can’t help bring a smile to my face. It must be said, that among all the wonderful examples, Lancaster goes gold hands down for the PEF (Picket Excellence Framework), and Imogen Tyler deserves a special award of excellence for her unwavering commitment to impact dissemination, Twitter-wide.

Here’s to all the dancers (and musicians) on the picket line

#fromthepicketline this morning @LancasterUCU Witt the Atomic Brass Band #ussstrikes #UCUstrike pic.twitter.com/y9OQJVvBDl

— Imogen Tyler (@ProfImogenTyler) March 15, 2018

I am striking today #day13 of #ussstrikes #ucustrikes against pension robbery & against the marketisation of universities — education is not a business it is a right #fromthepicketline #knowledgeispower #dancingourwaytochange pic.twitter.com/iJnjhFcRzX

— Imogen Tyler (@ProfImogenTyler) March 15, 2018

The @CityUCU Picket Band on tour… coming to a picket line near you… get down there and join in #usstrike pic.twitter.com/fPqTOFAM5c

— Ruth Windscheffel (@rcwApr10) March 12, 2018

Now @Dr_Robin_Smith giving a new twist to the Red Hot Chilli Peppers’ Californication @CardiffUCU #NoCapitulation pic.twitter.com/hPXOCpnWOM

— laurence totelin still on strike (@ltotelin) March 14, 2018

Day 10 on the picket lines. Double figures means double effort. Musically gifted, pensionally shafted #usstrike #ucustrike @CityUCU #USSstrikes pic.twitter.com/yx4UGoKCUH

— K Camps (@Karis_Kafro) March 12, 2018

@LancasterUCU strong finish to the picket today #NoCapitualtion pic.twitter.com/EsdgD58saz

— Anuja Pradhan (@anujap) March 16, 2018

Styling it. #UCUlancaster #angryducks pic.twitter.com/g8KzQ59Emq

— Lindsey Moore (@PocoLCMoore) March 7, 2018

Babies and mommies join the picket line @LancasterUni @LancasterUCU #Strike #strikeforUSS
Sling swingers! pic.twitter.com/JfdT1xPNMd

— Jacob Phelps (@_JPhelps) March 6, 2018

Amazing!! Local swing sling club came down to @LancasterUCU’s picket to show support and entertain us. #ucustrike pic.twitter.com/mgUh0RZQlt

— Christopher Hart (@_chris_hart) March 6, 2018

Dancing to atomic brass @LancasterUCU this morning #USStrike #ucustrike @ProfImogenTyler @jennashworth #fromthepicketline pic.twitter.com/uiPrdVOovB

— Maria Piacentini is between strikes (@piacenti) March 15, 2018

Atomic Brass slowing it down for a moment on @LancasterUCU picket line. pic.twitter.com/p1lpqe7so1

— Christopher Hart (@_chris_hart) March 15, 2018

Brilliant Atomic Brass paying us a visit at @LancasterUCU picket line this morning. pic.twitter.com/UER1N12OWu

— Christopher Hart (@_chris_hart) March 15, 2018

#thereallancasteruniversity #LancasterUCU Day 14 picket. Solidarity forever! No going back to the old ways. pic.twitter.com/wPyg76CPvY

— Lindsey Moore (@PocoLCMoore) March 16, 2018

Lancaster University has now been officially gold in PEF (Picket Excellence Framework) — & a special mention 5 for the interdisciplinary cross faculty “dancing queen” impact case study #fromthepicketline #ussstrike #ucustrike #solidarity is #everything @LancasterUCU pic.twitter.com/nNZiuWsRVn

— Imogen Tyler (@ProfImogenTyler) March 16, 2018

We’ve told the students we aren’t going to stop with the dad dancing till we secure our pensions — bad dancing is the new direct action pic.twitter.com/9eFbU8bPj1

— Imogen Tyler (@ProfImogenTyler) March 16, 2018

We’re still here! @sussexucu #ussstrikes #ucu strike #ucu pic.twitter.com/fX3fu70v9s

— Sussex Strike For USS Events (@sussex4ussevent) March 13, 2018

pic.twitter.com/ilmPIJsfEZ

— Imogen Tyler (@ProfImogenTyler) March 16, 2018

pic.twitter.com/ilmPIJsfEZ

— Imogen Tyler (@ProfImogenTyler) March 16, 2018

Putting fear into the heart of Pat Loughrey & senior management across the land / the #Goldsmiths @ucu Human League tribute band! #whereisPat #OneGoldsmiths #NoCapitulation #insolidarity #strikeforUSS #ucustrikes #highereducation #education #pensions pic.twitter.com/beKFwjvN91

— Goldsmiths UCU (@GoldsmithsUCU) March 16, 2018

pic.twitter.com/kHG1g6TMXy

— Goldsmiths UCU (@GoldsmithsUCU) March 16, 2018


For example, from Jason Hickel, David Kernohan, via Medium, etc. Karen Gregory has put together a list of UCU Strike Readings. Lucy Robinson’s strike scrapbook also deserves a special mention.
See by Six points on the eve of the UCU strike Jamie Woodcock

Your badges are awesome! Check out the ones we made @UoK_UCU for #USSstrike pic.twitter.com/90o96sZZAT

— Katja May (@may_katja) March 17, 2018


The post From the Picket Line appeared first on Alex Taylor.

item.title: PhD studentships at City
item.dc:creator: Alex Taylor
item.description:
Just trying to promote as widely as possible: My School has just announced ten PhD studentships. I’d love to have strong applications from prospective students wanting to join the Centre for Human-Centered Design (HCID). There’s a list of research topics here. The deadline is 25th April 2018. For the full advert, see here. Personally, I’m [...]

Read More... from PhD studentships at City

The post PhD studentships at City appeared first on Alex Taylor.
item.content:encoded:
Just trying to promote as widely as possible:

My School has just announced ten PhD studentships. I’d love to have strong applications from prospective students wanting to join the Centre for Human-Centered Design (HCID).

There’s a list of research topics here. The deadline is 25th April 2018. For the full advert, see here.

Personally, I’m very open to suggestions on topic. It would be thrilling to see proposals for critical and perhaps materialist orientations to technoscience. Oh, and feminist, intersectional thinking would be high on my wish list.

Whatever the persuasion, if you have friends, students, colleagues, etc. interested in doing something exciting, please put them in touch.

The post PhD studentships at City appeared first on Alex Taylor.
